The noise was deafening as one rose higher and higher near the safety wire and then he hit it just near me and fell and the bike fell too the wheels ﬂying round and his hand; all I remember is the bone sticking out and all the blood.

Courtown

Courtown was our Costa Brava for many years. The shops in those days closed for a half-day on Wednesdays, and many headed seaward then and on Sundays. Courtown had a sandy beach then, big enough for games of football, and spacious enough for hundreds to sit down in comfort.

Johnny Byrne regularly ran a bus called a charabanc to the sea and early in my life I saw a two-horse stagecoach with passengers inside and on top. When Mag Keppel saw the sea for the ﬁrst time, she exclaimed, ‘Jayze, will ya look at the size of the f…en river!’

Byrne’s charabanc was later converted and became a mobile home, permanently parked in Ireton’s ﬁeld. In the early 70’s I drove our Volks with eight passengers, three chaps over the engine and the rest almost comfortable.

A number of Tullow people had Summer homes there, soaking up the ozone. On one occasion when our family had rented a chalet in Ardamine my brother Tom and I walked into Courtown, bought a paper for Dad, hired a rowing boat and headed out the harbour for Ardamine. After delivering the paper we rowed back to the harbour. Life jacket? Unheard of then.

On day trips, Mother always brought a can of rice pudding. When cold it had to be carved out of the sweet can –delicious! We fought over the scrapings. You could buy a kettle of boiling water for a shilling. Lots of Tullovians went to the dances in the Tara Ballroom – they seemed to love music.

Lough Martin

For our Winter Sports we had Lough Martin which was a lough which formed each Winter between the Bunclody and Rathoe roads. It often was twelve acres or so, about the size of four football ﬁelds, and was mostly shallow.

In the Summer it usually dried out but in winter we slid around it in our hob-nailed boots. The only skaters were the Burgess ladies, Edna and Thea, and Rev. Studdart and the Hardy Eustaces. They had real skates. Eventually it was drained into the Slaney which in its way was ironic. It was on that ice that Dad broke his nose.

We also skated on the Square when a couple of buckets of water would put a good track on the road. In 1947 the Square was a great Winter playground after six or seven weeks of snow, and ice that lasted till May. The snow was pushed to one side but not before a bunch of us including P.J. Griﬃn, Patsy Fenelon and my brother, Liam decided to build a snowball.

As it got bigger we pushed it downhill to collect more snow and when it was five feet high it began to move itself and, gathering speed, it raced silently down Bridge Street. We gaped in awe at the monster and slunk home in case we had done harm.

Around that time Patsy went sliding down the hill in his Communion suit. As he gathered speed he lost control and couldn’t stop till he hit the slush. His mother just happened to come to the door and witnessed the daredevil. She wasn’t annoyed, she was incandescent, and a very sore Patsy was ﬂung in the door and wasn’t seen for a few days.

Ned Farrell and Larry Roche had their own use for the hill. They found an old lorry tyre and climbed in, each taking turns to propel the other at breakneck speed down the hill using their hob-nails as brakes as necessary. Thrill seekers!

The Vice Squad

The Vice Squad was very busy in the 50s and 60s. A small group, about twenty to thirty was engaged in clearly illegal activities from time to time, especially at weekends, and sometimes out in the open for all to see. The Gardai were determined to wipe out this blot on the reputation of the Force and restore the good name of the town.

The vice had become endemic and unsavoury persons from Carlow had been seen lurking around the town. Whenever a raid had been arranged the group seemed to melt away in the dark as if forewarned, and then they would turn up in a diﬀerent location just as diﬃcult to surprise. As the years went by the older Gardai left the job to the younger lot and tut-tutted at the shortcomings of youthful enthusiasm.

Eventually a trickle of prosperity became a rivulet and then a stream until ﬁnally the pestilence vanished. The ‘School of Pitch and Toss’ had closed down.

(Pitch and Toss was a gamble in which two half pence were tossed high in the air, and the participants bet whether two heads or harps or one of each would turn up. Even a fool could follow this game. Many did for years. One man lost £1,000 on a Christmas Day. Another unfortunate lost his farm, as he sold it bit by bit to feed his weakness. Edward told me he earned £18 for a week’s savage work in the beet ﬁelds, and lost whatever he did not give to the mother.)

The Children’s Allowance

We had no TV in the early 70s, as it was twenty-four hour snow, and to compensate we took our boys to Eason’s in Dublin with the Children’s Allowance. Government employees got a special allowance in those days, because they reckoned we were fecund and would people the land with obedient little taxpayers. Our boys could get six or seven books each, and it was easy to drive in Dublin, and Satan hadn’t yet thought of clamping.

We set out on our trip in our new Fiat 128 (second-hand), a real bargain. As the contented party set oﬀ home through Dame Street the Fiat felt a little sluggish. I stopped for a few minutes and tried again labouring up Christchurch Hill.

After a mile or so I had to stop. I hardly knew how to open the bonnet, but when I did I immediately recognised the problem – it was the ﬂames! Small ones but real and surprisingly hot. Panic! Fire blanket? ‘Esther, give me your coat!’ It was a duﬄe, new, and she looked cute in it. It covered the ﬂames nicely as they ﬂickered away. Just then an Angel appeared with a bucket of water – Whoosh. Problem solved.

New problem – how do we get home? Paddy Brennan answered the phone. ‘Eugene? What have ye done now?’ He laughed. ‘Of course I’ll drive to Dublin and tow home a ﬁre hazard.’ I was a wreck trying to keep my distance from him and wondering how on earth we would pay for it. Maybe Paddy would wait till the cow calved.

Tullow and the ‘cupla focail’

Ole yawn from the Irish Áilleán = a fool. ‘Will ye look at that ole yawn and the cut of him.’

Feac = a spade. ‘Where did ye lave the feac Jack ?’

Cruisteil = throwing stones. ‘Why were you throwing stones at the ﬁsh?’ ‘We weren’t throwing stones at the ﬁsh, yer honour, Sir. We were cruistin’ the ducks, yer Honour, Sir.’

Tullow Historian is delighted to again welcome Eugene O’Connor to this blog, and to give an on-line platform to Eugene’s second book which is inspired by local people and events. His first book can be found on Tough Times in Tullow – 1940s to the 1960s

ABOUT THE AUTHOR

The author was born in Tullow and taught there from 1969 until his retirement. He has had articles published in the Irish Press, the Irish Times and Business and Finance.

He enjoys searching the garden for seeds sowed some time ago. Most of the fish he caught surrendered.

INTRODUCTION

This book, a companion to Tough Times in Tullow, is quite unlike it in many ways. Though the tales are from Tullow, they cover Bombay, New York, Paris and Berlin. There is a Prince, a Ghost, and a too friendly domestic rodent. Some parts are 200 years old and others a mere 40 or so, with a death or two and a birth and a life saving. There is something here for the most fastidious reader, and something too for those who prefer plain unvarnished truths.

So, take this book, turn off the phone and the telly, lock the door and enjoy bits of a life that has been lived mostly in Tullow.

It has been put together with the help of many local people, whom I wish to thank here most sincerely. Anne Twomey, as “editor”, has been exceptional, and my family, Fergal, Daragh, and Gene, and especially the one without whom it would not have appeared, in name Esther.

1. ALARD VON ROHR

When Dr. Alard Von Rohr came to Tullow, Co. Carlow area in the 80s, he was house hunting, and he found and bought Newstown House, in Ardattin, a fine old Georgian building with about 20 or so acres.

His neighbour, Alec Twomey, soon introduced himself, welcomed him, and offered to help in any way he could. He quickly became his adviser and confidant. He was a God send to the Von Rohrs. Alard wanted to make some changes to the house and to build a vast exercise shed for his wife’s show jumping horses. She, Ruth, was on the German show jumping team and loved the sport.

When World War 2 started, Alard, who was from Prussia, was quickly captured by the Russians and spent the war in prison. His 4000-acre estate was confiscated and after his release he went to Berlin and set up a very successful security company which eventually employed 800 people.

We met the Von Rohr’s through Alec, who was my bridge partner. The Von Rohr’s had a beautiful home with a magnificent bog oak dining table and chairs, seating about twenty and lots of candelabra and so on, that would remind you of Downton Abbey. Alard was affable and struggling a little with his English, but he was a natural joker.

Some months later I got a call from Alec. The Von Rohr’s had a visitor from Germany. They had toured Ireland in 5-star luxury for three days, and on his last night, he wanted to visit a typical Irish pub. Where would I recommend? I thought first of ‘The Dying Cow’ which had featured on the front page of the New York Times, however it was difficult to find, even in daylight, so I suggested ‘The Fleece’ in Coolkenno, a couple of miles from each of us. He asked us to come along so he would not have to listen to German all night.

We arrived at ‘The Fleece’ early and were halfway through a drink when the others arrived. There was Alard and Ruth, and Alec, and a slightly portly gentleman in a beautiful suit with another man in the background. We were introduced, and the gentleman took Esther’s hand and in perfect courtly fashion – kissed it. When Ruth announced quietly, and it was an announcement, that the man was ‘Prince Louis Ferdinand’ – I was stunned.

You remember the photo of the Kaiser, Wilhelm the 2nd on his high horse with his steel helmet and the spike sticking up

– he was in all our history books?

Well this was his grandson, Prince Louis Ferdinand, the last of the Hohenzollerns, the Crown Prince of Germany. You remember the great Frederick the Great, whose exploits we struggled to remember, this Prince was a direct descendant and there he was, kissing my wife’s hand in Jack Carroll’s pub on a Winters’ night. This was no Prince William or Prince Charles; this man was History walking.

Would anyone believe me? For the rest of the night, I was tongue tied. I don’t meet Princes very often and I am afraid my natural volubility was cowed in the awesome presence.

The Prince’s English was perfect. He had worked in Chicago for a number of years for Henry Ford with a view of being the Ford representative. for Europe. He had a doctorate in economics and was an author and music composer. He had been in close contact with the Anti-Hitler groups. When it came time to go, Esther received another gracious kiss on her proffered hand – rather like Audrey Hepburn in ‘Roman Holiday’. I offered her the back seat in the Volkswagen on the drive home, but she graciously declined.

A couple of years later when we were at the house again, Alard showed us the Mausoleum he was having built for himself and Ruth. It was Greek in style, in cut granite, set among beech trees with branches tied back while building was in progress.

It fitted neatly into the beautiful surroundings. Alard knew what was coming. When Ruth died the cortege was led up the avenue by her favourite horse with her riding boots reversed in the stirrups. Within a few short years the major characters in the evening had passed away – The Prince, Ruth, Alard and their adviser and confidant, Alec Twomey. It brought home to me the brevity of history and the smallness of the world.

2. ALEC TWOMEY

Alec and Jo Twomey and their two children, John and Anne, arrived in the Tullow area directly from Massachusetts, U.S.A. They had decided Ireland might be a better place to rear a family and with that in mind had bought a parcel of land, 77 acres in Craans, Ardattin, with the initial leg work done by his brother Christy. A mobile home was installed for the family to live in, before Alec set about building a bungalow.

After consulting the experts, he decided against their advice, and planted an orchard of 7,000 apple trees, Golden Delicious and Odin, and in due course they bore fruit for their expected 20+ years. How would he dispose of his crops? The Dublin market was rejected as they wanted a large portion of the profit, so he decided to sell direct from the farm. And he made it work. Many local people found work there at different times including our own children. There was the thinning in May and June, tying branches July through October and the picking and sorting in time for Halloween.

Alec had left Ballyvourney, Co. Cork in 1947 after a spell in the Army and had gone to a cousin in Boston. His trip across the Atlantic was very stormy and he and three others were the only ones not affected, and they were fed lavishly for the journey whiling away the hours playing bridge, a game whose challenges he loved. His cousin in Boston guided and encouraged him and he soon began to prosper.

He started as a dispatcher in a trucking business, and worked his way through the ranks, then when his chance came to buy a local business he grabbed it and grew it to a seven-truck outfit.

The apple business thrived. Great care was taken with the crop. He could be seen at 4 or 5 a.m. spraying before any breeze got up that would cause spray drift. Every child who came with parents got an apple and everyone knew the ‘Apple Man’. A grading machine was installed to sort the apples and when the crop was sold the shed was transformed into a badminton court and roller skate rink.

The children of the area had a great time. As many as twenty locals turned up on Winter nights for games which kept them from hankering after town life. One Summer R.A. Keppels’ boat was sawn in half and an 8-foot section added to it. That operation was a sight to behold and was typical of the ingenuity and confidence he brought to every enterprise. To his mind everything was possible.

When my Bluebird was developing rust he took it in, cured it by screwing a long thin piece of lath into the lid of the boot to facilitate its repair, and that Bluebird was the only one in the country with woodworm. When Christmas came he drove his tractor and trailer with bales for seating and choir of carolers around the town for charity. On another occasion we figured it out that it was his £50 note that turned up in a school charity box at a time when a tenner was real money.

Alec started his local water scheme. He rallied the neighbours, planned it and built it, was carpenter, plumber, electrician and general go-getter for the enterprise. He was Von Rohr’s right-hand man, confidant and money-minder, ensuring that all money was spent locally. When his friend Charlie became infirm he got him into the Cheshire Home and when Charlie passed away the home was amply rewarded.

The above only gives a hint of what a power for good he was for the community. I am sure the people were greatly enriched by his presence and his activities in the area.

Ar Dheis De Go Raibh A Anam.

3. FEAR OF WATER

It took a very long time to develop a fear of water, mainly because of ignorance and stupidity. There were warnings in plenty but as no one in my memory had drowned in the Slaney river, the dangers were not heeded. In 2015 I first heard how one strong swimmer, Michael Murphy (Mick, of Thomas Traynor Road) had saved three youngsters in the same afternoon. Well done Mick, how lucky you were there! My first dangerous encounter happened in the Slaney, in a harmless looking part of the river. Moving downstream from the others close to the bank was just an adventure until I felt the current pulling a bit stronger as the water became chest high. At the same time the gravel began to move under my feet and panic set in, enough to make me silent. I reached for a branch; it broke.

Again, this time barely clutching the slim shoot and slowly increasing the pressure and reaching up further. My pals had disappeared from sight and earshot. A foot reached out under the bush, a little shallower. The water was pushing me downstream. My foot reached again – unexpectedly shallower under the bank. The crisis was over and with more confidence there was a stronger branch and I moved slowly upstream to safety and climbed onto the bank, and for a half hour pretended it was a lovely day.

On a brisk hot day at Ardamine the waves were crashing vigorously on our bodies. It was very refreshing. It was waist high in the troughs and after a while the exhilaration paled, and I started heading ashore. The sand slipped under my feet at each attempted step. Again, and again it happened. No progress. I was afraid again, and it paralyses. I couldn’t throw myself in and swim as I hated getting my head under water. Luckily a wave threw me further in and I stumbled ashore. There was no talking for a while.

That silent thing happened again when three of us were fishing off Hook Head and having no luck. We steamed slowly towards the lighthouse searching for gulls and mackerel. After a while the waves seemed much higher than our little boat especially coming near the point. Then I noticed the lighthouse disappeared for a moment. That was one big wave, and then silence reigned as the skipper tried to turn without shipping water. Slowly but surely, we got out of danger.
